quoteFirst: At twelve by my clock the room was dark. We were very busy then. I looked up again at
quoteLast: by _my_ clock here, a minute past twelve by my own watch, which I always keep right by Greenwich, and it's a good chronometer, as you know----"
title: Miracle Gold: A Novel (Vol. 1 of 3)
author: Dowling, Richard, 1846-1898

quoteFirst: He looked at the illuminated dial of his watch; the hands, the numerals, greenly phosphorescent, were sharp; it was midnight. After apparently an interminable wait he looked again--
quoteLast: . The rumble of an elevated train approached, hung about the room, and receded. Death could be no more dragging than this.
title: Cytherea
author: Hergesheimer, Joseph, 1880-1954

quoteFirst: “Speaks for himself” every evening this month. On the 1st, he rises at 10:34 a. m., and on the 2d sets at
quoteLast: ; on the 16th, rises at 9:50 a. m., and sets at 11:16 p. m.; and on the 30th, rises at 9:03 a. m., and sets at 10:23 p. m.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 05, June 1885, No. 9
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]

quoteLast: —The Stillness of a Grave XI. 12:15 a. m.—To Watch by Night XII. 12:30 a. m.
title: Murder by the clock
author: King, Rufus, 1893-1966

quoteFirst: On the 31st she sets at 12:12 a. m.; on the 15th, rises at 11:25 p. m.; on the 31st, sets at
quoteLast: On the meridian, 1st at 5:56¼ p. m.; on the 15th, at 3:58 a. m.; on 30th, at 5:30 p. m. Farthest from the earth, 10th at 7:24 p. m.; nearest the earth on 24th, at 1:36 p. m.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 04, May 1884, No. 8
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]

quoteLast: the mail-train came thundering out of nowhere.
title: The end of the trail
author: Powell, E. Alexander (Edward Alexander), 1879-1957

quoteFirst: The result of those labours of which it is not for me to appreciate the importance have long since been published. My map of the Rio Magdalena, multiplied by the copies of the year 1802 in America and Spain, and comprehending the country between Almaguer and Santa Marta, from 1 degree
quoteLast: 1 degrees 15 minutes latitude, appeared in 1816. Till that period no traveller had undertaken to describe New Grenada; and the public, except in Spain, knew the navigation of the Magdalena only by some lines traced by Bouguer.
title: Personal Narrative of Travels to the Equinoctial Regions of America, During the Year 1799-1804 — Volume 3
author: Humboldt, Alexander von, 1769-1859; Bonpland, Aimé, 1773-1858; Ross, Thomasina [Translator]
